mainEntity.name: Is it better to build a home when rates are dropping?

acceptedAnswer.text: Building can be a strong strategy in a declining rate environment because you can lock a rate during construction and use a float-down if rates drop further. Seasonal builder incentives in Myrtle Beach can also improve affordability.

mainEntity.name: Is it better to build or buy a new home for investment purposes?

acceptedAnswer.text: Buying a new build provides immediate rental potential, while building allows customization that maximizes income. Many investors build so they can include features like multiple suites, bunk rooms, or upgraded outdoor spaces.

mainEntity.name: How does inventory affect my build or buy decision?

acceptedAnswer.text: Improved inventory gives buyers more choices, but Myrtle Beach hot spots still move quickly. Buyers needing specific layouts may benefit more from building.

mainEntity.name: How do I design a coastal home that’s safer in a flood?

acceptedAnswer.text: Elevate living areas above Base Flood Elevation, keep mechanicals off the ground, use flood-friendly materials on lower levels, and prioritize proper grading and drainage. Work with a builder familiar with FEMA maps and local codes.

mainEntity.name: Do inland Myrtle Beach communities still need flood-smart layouts?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Heavy rain events can overwhelm inland drainage systems. Elevated mechanicals, flood-aware storage planning, and smart ground-floor use help reduce risk even outside mapped flood zones.

mainEntity.name: How do I find out what flood zone my Myrtle Beach property is in?

acceptedAnswer.text: Use FEMA’s Flood Map Service Center or Horry County’s online flood map viewer. Myrtle Beach Construction Services and Chapin Memorial Library can assist with historic maps and explanations.

mainEntity.name: How high should I elevate my new home in Horry County?

acceptedAnswer.text: AE zones require the lowest floor 3 feet above BFE. VE zones require the lowest supporting member 3 feet above BFE. A-zones without BFE require at least 24 inches above the highest adjacent grade. Many elevate even higher to reduce risk and insurance costs.

mainEntity.name: Are Elevation Certificates still useful with FEMA’s Risk Rating 2.0?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. They aren't required to buy flood insurance, but can help lower premiums and provide clear documentation for buyers, lenders, and insurers.

mainEntity.name: What flood and wind mitigation incentives are available in South Carolina?

acceptedAnswer.text: Myrtle Beach’s CRS Class 5 rating can reduce NFIP premiums. SC Safe Home offers grants for wind retrofits. FORTIFIED roofs can qualify for discounts with certain carriers.

mainEntity.name: Does building higher improve my home’s resale value?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Buyers prefer elevated homes with lower flood premiums, documented risk reduction, and less storm-related concern. These homes often attract stronger offers.

mainEntity.name: Can I get flood insurance in an X zone?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. NFIP policies are available in X zones, often at lower preferred rates. While not required, they add peace of mind for buyers.

mainEntity.name: What is aging in place?

acceptedAnswer.text: It means designing or adapting a home to be safe and comfortable as you age. In coastal areas, it also includes flood resilience, accessibility, and durable materials.

mainEntity.name: Which home modifications are most important for aging in place?

acceptedAnswer.text: Key features include main-level suites, wide doors, curbless showers, lever handles, strong lighting, motion sensors, and non-slip flooring.

mainEntity.name: How can a multi-generational layout benefit my home design long term?

acceptedAnswer.text: Private bedroom suites, guest quarters, or ADU-style spaces can flex into rental units, caregiver suites, or guest rooms over time.

mainEntity.name: What is a multi-generational home?

acceptedAnswer.text: A home where multiple adult generations live under one roof, often featuring separate living zones, dual suites, or an ADU.

mainEntity.name: Why are multi-generational floor plans becoming more popular?

acceptedAnswer.text: Rising housing costs, aging parents needing support, and adult children returning home have increased demand for layouts supporting multiple generations.

mainEntity.name: Does an elevator add value to a coastal home?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not always necessary to install immediately, but planning for one significantly improves long-term livability and resale appeal.

mainEntity.name: Is rising inventory bad for sellers in Coastal South Carolina?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not necessarily. It often signals a healthier, more balanced market. Well-priced and well-presented homes still attract strong offers.

mainEntity.name: How should I price my home when more listings are available?

acceptedAnswer.text: Use accurate neighborhood comparables. Correct pricing reduces days on market and helps avoid early price drops.

mainEntity.name: Are homes still selling quickly in Myrtle Beach?

acceptedAnswer.text: Some do, especially in desirable areas like Market Common and Carolina Forest, though days on market have normalized statewide.

mainEntity.name: What upgrades matter most to today's buyers?

acceptedAnswer.text: Move-in-ready features like fresh paint, updated fixtures, clean landscaping, and well-maintained systems consistently perform well.

mainEntity.name: Does increased inventory mean I’ll have to accept a lower offer?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not if your home offers clear value. Strong presentation and strategic pricing often outweigh market-wide inventory trends.

mainEntity.name: Will mortgage rates really drop in early 2026?

acceptedAnswer.text: Analographers expect modest rate relief as inflation cools, improving affordability for buyers.

mainEntity.name: Are home prices expected to rise in 2026?

acceptedAnswer.text: South Carolina home prices rose modestly in 2024. If rates drop, demand may increase prices slightly.

mainEntity.name: Will Myrtle Beach condos be a good option in 2026?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Condos account for over 30% of coastal sales and remain strong for affordability and ease of maintenance.

mainEntity.name: Are new builds good for vacation rentals in Myrtle Beach?

acceptedAnswer.text: New builds offer modern layouts, efficiency, and amenities that boost nightly rates and reduce maintenance costs.

mainEntity.name: Which Myrtle Beach areas are best for new-build vacation rentals?

acceptedAnswer.text: Strong-performing areas include Market Common, North Myrtle Beach, Carolina Forest, and Surfside Beach.

mainEntity.name: What trends are driving Myrtle Beach vacation rental demand?

acceptedAnswer.text: Inbound migration, remote work, multigenerational travel, and upgraded amenities continue to raise demand.

mainEntity.name: How many bedrooms should a rental-friendly beach home have?

acceptedAnswer.text: Three to five bedrooms with one bunk room and multiple living areas provide strong rental performance without overcrowding.
